articles.headline: An Exodus of Agents Left the Secret Service Unprepared for 2024
articles.snippet: Punishing hours, dilapidated facilities and an ill-conceived retiree program left the agency without the personnel it needed in a year of threats and violence.
articles.abstract: Punishing hours, dilapidated facilities and an ill-conceived retiree program left the agency without the personnel it needed in a year of threats and violence.
articles.lead_paragraph: In November, Michael Ebey, a Secret Service special agent, found himself working another 12-hour shift. Like so many before, it was grueling.
articles.byline: By Eric Lipton and David A. Fahrenthold

articles.headline: Around Dallas, the Church Scandals Seem to Have No End
articles.snippet: In this part of Texas, a pastor with a clean reputation is not to be taken for granted.
articles.abstract: In this part of Texas, a pastor with a clean reputation is not to be taken for granted.
articles.lead_paragraph: On a Sunday morning, the pastor of Fellowship Church in Grapevine, Texas, took the stage with his wife to reassure their congregation.

articles.headline: U.S. Faces Economic Turbulence Just as Recession Fears Eased
articles.snippet: War in the Middle East, a strike by port workers and a devastating hurricane injected uncertainty into the U.S. economy.
articles.abstract: War in the Middle East, a strike by port workers and a devastating hurricane injected uncertainty into the U.S. economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: The United States economy is suddenly staring down new and potentially damaging crises, with tensions flaring in the Middle East and several states grappling with fallout from a devastating hurricane.
articles.byline: By Alan Rappeport and Ana Swanson

articles.headline: Filing in Trump Election Case Fleshes Out Roles of a Sprawling Cast
articles.snippet: Donald Trump is the only defendant in the special counsel’s case that charges him with a plot to remain in power after his 2020 loss. But a newly unsealed brief provides fresh details about many other figures.
articles.abstract: Donald Trump is the only defendant in the special counsel’s case that charges him with a plot to remain in power after his 2020 loss. But a newly unsealed brief provides fresh details about many other figures.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the special counsel, Jack Smith, charged former President Donald J. Trump last year with plotting to overturn the 2020 election, the federal indictment filed in Washington had only one defendant: Mr. Trump himself, who stood accused of working with a small team of conspirators.
articles.byline: By Alan Feuer and Charlie Savage

articles.headline: 3 Former Officers Acquitted of Most Serious Charge in Tyre Nichols’s Death
articles.snippet: The former officers were found guilty of witness tampering but not of the charge that would have held them responsible for causing his death.
articles.abstract: The former officers were found guilty of witness tampering but not of the charge that would have held them responsible for causing his death.
articles.lead_paragraph: Three former Memphis police officers were found guilty on Thursday of federal witness tampering charges in the fatal beating of Tyre Nichols, a 29-year-old Black man. But all three defendants were acquitted of the more serious charge of violating his civil rights by causing his death.
articles.byline: By Emily Cochrane and Ben Stanley

articles.headline: As America’s Marijuana Use Grows, So Do the Harms
articles.snippet: The drug, legal in much of the country, is widely seen as nonaddictive and safe. For some users, these assumptions are dangerously wrong.
articles.abstract: The drug, legal in much of the country, is widely seen as nonaddictive and safe. For some users, these assumptions are dangerously wrong.
articles.lead_paragraph: In midcoast Maine, a pediatrician sees teenagers so dependent on cannabis that they consume it practically all day, every day — “a remarkably scary amount,” she said.
articles.byline: By Megan Twohey, Danielle Ivory and Carson Kessler

articles.headline: Kamala Harris and the Influence of an Estranged Father Just Two Miles Away
articles.snippet: Donald J. Harris rarely speaks to his famous daughter, who lives nearby. But he helped shape who she became.
articles.abstract: Donald J. Harris rarely speaks to his famous daughter, who lives nearby. But he helped shape who she became.
articles.lead_paragraph: Kamala Harris recalled a childhood memory of her father in her convention speech two months ago, when she said he exhorted her in an unnamed park to “Run, Kamala, run. Don’t be afraid. Don’t let anything stop you.”

articles.headline: Pandemic Start-Ups Are Thriving, and Helping to Fuel the Economy
articles.snippet: A record surge in new businesses has helped drive job growth, and could have longer-term benefits.
articles.abstract: A record surge in new businesses has helped drive job growth, and could have longer-term benefits.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hector Xu was on track for a career in academia when the pandemic upended his plans.
articles.byline: By Ben Casselman and Sydney Ember

articles.headline: ‘Mom, I Want to Live’: A Young Girl Battles War and Cancer
articles.snippet: Sonya Liakh was diagnosed with eye cancer at age 2. After Russia’s invasion of Ukraine disrupted her treatment, her family faced a desperate struggle.
articles.abstract: Sonya Liakh was diagnosed with eye cancer at age 2. After Russia’s invasion of Ukraine disrupted her treatment, her family faced a desperate struggle.
articles.lead_paragraph: Splayed out on a pink bedspread, wearing a pink tank top and surrounded by stuffed pink unicorns, 6-year-old Sonya Liakh unscrewed the port to the catheter in her chest. She took a pre-filled syringe of morphine from the tray held by the nurse beside her, deftly inserted the syringe into her port, and pushed the contents into her jugular vein.

articles.headline: Europe Raises Tariffs on China’s E.V.s, Confronting a Key Trade Partner
articles.snippet: European Union officials say the duties are meant to protect the region’s automakers from what they say are unfair trade practices in China.
articles.abstract: European Union officials say the duties are meant to protect the region’s automakers from what they say are unfair trade practices in China.
articles.lead_paragraph: The European Union voted on Friday to impose higher tariffs on electric vehicles imported from China, risking tensions with an important trading partner in an effort to protect an industry crucial to Europe’s economy.
articles.byline: By Melissa Eddy and Jenny Gross

articles.headline: Labor Market Shows Unexpected Strength
articles.snippet: U.S. employers added 254,000 jobs in September, a sign that economic growth remained solid. The unemployment rate fell to 4.1 percent.
articles.abstract: U.S. employers added 254,000 jobs in September, a sign that economic growth remained solid. The unemployment rate fell to 4.1 percent.
articles.lead_paragraph: Many have doubted it. Even the optimists have worried about it. But despite the hand-wringing, the American economy appears to be in remarkably good shape.
